arm_group.description: 0.5 mg/kg ketamine intra-nasally; then 0.25 mg/kg repeat dose after 10 minutes if necessary

brief_summary.textblock:
The provision of analgesia to patients in pain is a fundamental necessity of emergency
      department practice and is usually accomplished using IV opioids. However, significant
      barriers exist to the provision of timely analgesia by the IV route.

      The use of the IN route for medication delivery provides an efficient and relatively
      painless mode of analgesia delivery. As well, ketamine is well-known to be an effective
      analgesic and to preserve cardiorespiratory function thus removing the necessity of
      physiologic monitoring that is obligatory when using opioids.  The use of ketamine by the IN
      route provides a rapid, easy-administered and well-tolerated method for providing analgesia
      in the ED setting.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intra-nasal Ketamine for Analgesia in the Emergency Department

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  age 6 years or greater

          -  moderate or severe pain (VAS >=50mm)

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  history of allergy or intolerance to ketamine

          -  structural or functional nasal occlusion

          -  inability to understand the VAS

          -  Glasgow Coma Scale < 15

          -  Systolic BP > 180

          -  History of schizophrenia

          -  Clinical necessity for immediate IV access as judged by the treating physician

clinical_study.official_title: Intra-nasal Ketamine for Analgesia in the Emergency Department

overall_official.affiliation: UBC Dept of EM; Lions Gate Hospital

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of subjects achieving a 13mm or more reduction in pain as measured on a 100-mm VAS within 30 minutes.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor, University of British Columbia Department of Emergency Medicine; Attending Physician and Emergency Department Research Director, Lions Gate Hospital

secondary_outcome.measure: Median maximum reduction in VAS pain score achieved within 30 minutes
Median time required to achieve a 13-mm reduction in VAS pain score

secondary_outcome.description: Changes in vital signs will be recorded every 5 minutes for 30 minutes, then every 10 minutes for 30 minutes
secondary_outcome.measure: Vital signs changes (ETCO2, O2sat, HR, RR, BP)

secondary_outcome.description: SERSDA (Side Effect Rating Scale for Dissociative Anaesthesia) includes: fatigue, dizziness, nausea, headache, feeling of unreality, changes in hearing, changes in vision, mood change, generalized discomfort, and hallucination.
secondary_outcome.measure: Adverse effects as defined by SERSDA

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
